answers.author: Alexandra Iannolo
answers.text:
Hello,
A similar question to this has been asked before. Below is the link to what others shared in past.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/questions/question/20619 
While researching some more recent studies, I found a guideline put together by the Association of Local Government Auditors of what an effective staffing plan looks like. It also gives suggestions on how to conduct your own staffing analysis.
http://www.governmentauditors.org/index.php/quarterly-articles-mainmenu-123/436-an-overview-of-staffing-analysis-spring-2009 
The homepage of the Auditor’s Office in Texas also has a detailed workforce planning guide posted. I have also included a link to their 2006 workforce analysis which may offer some assistance.
http://sao.hr.state.tx.us/workforce/guide.html#Overview
http://www.sao.state.tx.us/reports/main/07-707.pdf
I was also able to find a recent workforce analysis from three different states.
Minnesota-http://www.auditor.leg.state.mn.us/ped/2010/workforcesum.htm
Georgia- http://www.spa.ga.gov/word/wfp/wfp.EnterpriseReFY09.pdf
Wisconsin- 
http://oser.state.wi.us/docview.asp?docid=6309
As far as suggesting consultants, the links below may help while researching firms that best fit their needs.
http://www.consultingmag.com/rankings_top25.htm
http://www.kennedyinfo.com/consulting/research/public-sector-marketplace
I hope these links are helpful!
Ali Iannolo
ICMA Knowledge Network Intern
aiannolo@ICMA.org
